title: Fun To Walk and Shop - Don't Miss The Steamclock
reviews: Every cruise ship passenger ends up having a walk in gas town for a stroll, a shop at the tourist marts and of course the steam clock.  Best to see the steamclock at noon for the big show.

title: Small slice of Vancouver history...
reviews: Very touristy; lots of  'souvenir' shops.  Cool place to go, if you're a tourist, here for the first time.

title: Day trip!
reviews: My kids and I love to just wander enjoying the many shops and just the feel of the area.  Our tradition includes The Olde Spagetti Factory.... just because it's a fun place to be.  On a nice day sitting outside and watching the people go by is a great way to relax and enjoy each others company.

title: Worth a Couple of Hours
reviews: Worth a short stop just to see the Steam Clock go off on the hour.  Kinda touristy but there are some nice shops and galleries and eateries.  A few beggars and homeless that are bothersome so go before dark just to be safer.

title: So pretty
reviews: Visually this area is nice to walk through with all the restaurants, pubs, and stores. This was one of the stops of the many hop on hop off tour buses.

title: A Great Place for Totem Pole Souviners
reviews: We went to Gastown to look for inexpensive totem poles for our grandkids. There were a number of souviner shops. We found some at 137 Water st.

title: Must see!
reviews: This was one of our favorite parts of our visit to Vancouver. Fun shopping, good places to eat, and fun to walk around.

title: Great people watching, and lunch al fresco
reviews: Walk the market to build an appetite, then order from the take-away stands and go outside with the seagulls.

title: Overhyped colonial area
reviews: Other than the steam clock, and the fact that Gastown is yet another nice, colonial, walkable area like you can find in many other places, I honestly don't get the fascination of the area.

title: Great restaurants, a lot of homelessness
reviews: My husband and I heard great things about Gastown in Vancouver and decided to take a stroll there the day before our Alaska cruise. There were a lot of excellent restaurant choices, but we were overwhelmed by the amount of homeless people we had to deal with. Some of these restaurants are located in alleyways and on several occasions, we just felt unsafe.

title: good restaurants but not much else
reviews: As an 'old town' neighbourhood to visit, it's pretty lame.  But recently there have been a lot of really great restaurants opening, from Boneto, Calabash, The Diamond, etc  So stroll around in the evening, have a drink at The Diamond, then go for dinner somewhere else in the area.  And don't go too far into sketchy-ville.

title: Don't bother
reviews: Phew! what a contrast to other parts of Vancouver! Outrageous parking prices. If you can find somewhere to park. Shabby with lots of homeless beggars trying to sell free leaflets. Not worth a visit. It might taint your opinion of Vancouver.

title: Great, but sketchy too.
reviews: Stayed at the Pan Pacific nearby. Can walk to Gas Town. It has some very nice true native art galleries and art shops, which we loved! There are also cute coffee shops b There are also touristy shops for the cruise people. I think it's manageable for a day and recommend it for a stop. Getting there you deal with homeless people, addicts and the mentally ill. It's very sad. It gets worse if you walk beyond Gas Town on the way to Chinatown. I was grateful for the many cruise people walking around. They made me feel safer. If you want to get to Chinatown and avoid the really sketchy area you might take the skytrain from the Waterfront area. There is a stop in Chinatown.

title: a wonderful wander!
reviews: We had such a great time strolling around Gastown.  The architecture was fantastic and the history in this part of the city was so interesting.  The steam clock was fun to see, and the hustle and bustle of the area was invigorating.  There are plenty of shops and cafes to keep you busy and well fed; enjoying an outdoor lunch at one of the sidewalk cafes while people watching made for a fabulous afternoon.  A wonderful neighborhood in a wonderful city!

title: Clock is so cool
reviews: Loved the whistling gas clock! Gastown is a neat area with cobblestones and lots of history. Interesting architecture is everywhere, and streets go every-which-way - took us ages to find Blood Alley etc. to the resto we wanted (but was worth it)   ;-D

title: Lovely
reviews: Very quaint and old fashioned part of the city.  The steam clock is such a great attraction but keep looking up at some of the old buildings.

title: Great place to wander and stop for a meal
reviews: So much to see here including the gassy jack clock which makes a lovely tune on the hour from memory, just sit at one of the outdoor cafes and watch the people go by and hear the clock go off, very different. We wandered around so long, shopping etc that we ended up getting dinner here and then it was a new experience again with all the lights. Lovely place.

title: Lovely
reviews: We really enjoyed our time in Gastown.  Lovely galleries, good food and vet importantly good coffee and the area has lots if character.  The steam clock is also great.  Definitely worth wandering around this area for a few hours.

title: Neat place to see
reviews: Gastown is right by the Waterfront in Vancouver and if you are down in the area, you really need to take a stroll through it.  It was the first commercial downtown of Vancouver, so it has some history.  They've made a point of preserving a lot of the old buildings and there are both restaurants and shopping available.  The Gas Clock is neat to see and here, and it's pretty scenic so if you like snapping photos, you'll have some good material to work with.We went once for just a stroll through the area, and then we went back again to have dinner one night and found it very enjoyable both time.Take Translink to Waterfront station and it's within easy walking distance.

title: Gassy Jack would be proud
reviews: Great way to spend a day with its many different shops and restaurants. Good place to take out of town visitors.

title: Interesting place for a wander
reviews: Again fab feel to the area, flowers everywhere, statue of gassy jack and the steam clock (which plays the Westminster chimes every 15 minutes) are worth a look at and some interesting historic buildings mingled with a wide range of expensive shops and some unusual ones too.

title: cobblestone streets?
reviews: Brick, actually, not cobblestone. Shops are pretty boring, needs more than the usual tourist carvings, posters and t-shirts. This street is a hollow reminder of what it was in the 70's, when it actually had remains of some cobblestone, a thriving old department store or two, several head shops,artist's studios, a big metal sculpting workshop (Harmon Foundry), Indian import shops, corner stores and diner cafes. Way too squeaky clean these days. One bright spot is the SFU expansion into the area, at least they have commemorated the place with a large black and white mural in their atrium  of the GrassTown Smoke-in, circa 1970 ish, when RCMP made headlines bashing harmless teenybopper heads in with billysticks.

title: Not really much here, but loved the steam clock
reviews: Gastown is the oldest part of Vancouver, but that only makes the buildings a little over 100 years old, so you've probably seen plenty of places with more history.  The architecture is Victorian, the shops and restaurants are tourist oriented, and the area is only a few blocks long, so it's easy to cover.  The best feature is the steam clock, especially if you're there when it plays a steam whistle version of the Westminster chimes (at least that's what I think the tune is).

title: Steam Clock
reviews: Gastown is full of shops and some restaurants ... it's good for a quick visit depending on what you enjoy.  The steam clock is interesting and gathers a crowd every 15 minutes.  Overall this area could be improved ... good if you need a few souvenirs.

title: What fun
reviews: We walked all over gastown... Love the steam clock... so many fun and ecclectic stores... interesting restaurants... went to La Casista for supper where the serve Mexican food... I had my mind changed by the most wonderful guacamole salad I have ever tasted in my life.. I have always disliked it until that meal... I will return... the steak with the enchiladas on top were great... Salsa's are spicy for me but I am a mild spice eater.  Everone else loved the heat

title: OK, I guess
reviews: We didn't stay down there very much.  It just didn't have any real appeal to us - thought it would be different but just any commercial area.

title: Not worth the effort
reviews: Only really Water St for a few blocks, and mostly junk touristy shops or boutiques. As others have said, needs to be a pedestrian mall. Old Montreal is far better, so don't waste your time going here.

title: Another Spot Making Vancouver Unique
reviews: Bars, restaurants, funky clothing and furniture, interesting old buildings all in abundance here. There really is no place like Gastown anwwhere else

title: kinda like victoria
reviews: Kinda like Victoria, but smaller, and more homeless people :-(

title: Trip to Canada
reviews: Gastown was great. There is so much to see and do. The area has a lot of history to it. However, do not venture beyond Gastown to the south once you reach the eastern most end. The area gets iffy really fast. There are plenty of restaurants in Gastown, galleries, and gift shops. Watch what you buy because you my find it elsewhere cheaper. Also, if you park on the street be aware the meters do not take the new Canadian coinage and the homeless jam up the meter and retrieve the coinage later. Ran into that problem. So either use a credit card or pay by cell phone. This way you will not loose a bunch of money in the meters. By the way, the ticket is $35 CA. I was told this by the merchants who line the street. So beware.

title: Reunion
reviews: Wandered around with old friends then had lunch at Water St Cafe which was very good.  On the following week I visited with another friend and we lunched at Pour House which was excellent then we shopped - great time.

title: Tourist Trap...
reviews: Like any tourist trap...there is a lack of great spaces that would require lounging around under an umbrella sipping a beer or coffee...enough with the Tourist Junk stores....make this a destination rather than a trap.Underdeveloped as a pedestrian space again...cars and buses running through...not a good idea...

title: Go for a stroll.....
reviews: Gastown isn't quite as vibrant as it used to be, but still worth a stroll around.  Gift shops, cafes and pubs..... still worth a visit.

title: shopping trip
reviews: great shops and restaurants. atmosphere great different shopsthat are unique and articulture is a beautiful site.

title: Old World
reviews: It was interesting, within walking distance and had old world ambiance. A lot of the historic elements were preserved and in working order. The Gastown gas clock is a must see, fantastic!

title: A fun place to visit
reviews: We enjoyed walking around Gastown and doing some pub crawling and shopping. It is a great place for souvenirs and people watching. Make sure you see the steam clock.

title: An antique
reviews: A must place to visit if you are in vancouver, Reminds of the old heritage of the Canadian culture and at every 200 Meters you will find the tours bus rental. The restaurants serve traditional food. Also do not forget to shop for the lucky jades

title: Lovely bars
reviews: Gastown is a great area. Recommended bars and eateries - Meat and Bread for lunch, The Diamond for cocktails

title: Historic Vancouver!
reviews: I LOVE GASTOWN! SO nice and historic, cool boutiques and lovely ambiance.  Only downside is that it's close to downtown east side which is vancouver's skid row.

title: Nice walk and lots of souvenirs
reviews: You can see tons of bums in this place, but thats cool. Here you will find tons of small restaurants and souvenir shops. I found a store with really high quality leather at very low prices... wish I could remember the name. You will find a lot of tourists here and a be wary of the bums.A lot of them look like serious druggies.Great place to walk around and chill in the summer. You can also see the water from here. We were told not to venture much towards the city, since the area can get a little shady at night.

title: Not for the faint of heart, unless wise and educated about the area.
reviews: First off I must stress that the location of Gastown is right next to Heroin Alley and the nucleus of all the junkies, druggies, crazy, homeless, distraught, vagrants, and freaking weird people. The center all this mess is basically at the intersection of hastings and main street. Within a 5 block radius, you will come across many a junkie, with frequencies rising the closer you get to the the aforementioned center. I only wish to convey this cleary because my girlfriend and I were walking through on Water Street and were passing a doorway to a shop and saw a a junkie with a syringe shooting up something, heroin, crack, i dont know, he then pulled out the needle and started to rub his face like he was really tired. I have never been so close to that sort of thing and it just really didnt sit well with me throughout the rest of the day. From what ive been reading that sort of thing can happen in plain sight quite often.  The place can be very distrubing if you come across the wrong people. Other than the the thrashy people, the gastown area is quite quaint and pleasant. The steam clock is great, its bigger than i thought and the steam can really cloud up above it. the main strip is cobblestoned road and sidewalk and thats always nice. The main square was really something. Its reminded me of a tiny old timesquare or something very similar to the five points in Gangs of New York with Gassy Jack overlooking the phole 5 way zone. The alleys in Gastown are something to steer clear of. We saw on the flyer a trounce alley and it was recommending checking it out, but it looked like every other alley in the East Downtown area. Very weary. The stores and restaurants in the area are very nice and well maintained. Prices are high as the place is a tourist attraction. Nothing crazy though. If it wasnt for the wild folks in the area it would be a good time, but for me personally, they tainted and semi ruined the experience. I recommend making a short trip of it, staying on water street seeing the steam clock and gassy jack towards the end and then getting the hell out of there.The city officials or government needs to do something about all those people ruining the area. Depending on your perception of the people, you will obviously have a different view on what to think of it all. I dont know how dangerous they can be to people, but im positive that theyre unstable and thats never as safe sober folks. I wouldnt bring my grandma here.

title: Small shopping district with cute shops
reviews: Not much to see other than the steam clock and a few cute shops. It is worth visiting if you have a couple of hours to kill. Lots of souvenir shops.

title: Old Vancouver with heritage buildings
reviews: Excellent to shop for souvenirs.  There are many new shops and restaurants.  The area is not good at night for families, being next to  the skid road area.

title: Nice area, tourist prices, too many vagrants
reviews: This is an area of pretty (but very over-priced) shops and bars. While the area itself is pleasant they have a massive problem with vagrants. It was bad walking to Gastown from downtown but not quite so bad in Gastown itself. When we decided to follow a tourist sign an walk to Chinatown the route took us down a very dubious street which did not feel safe, the street contained a mission so it was a focal point for needy locals.The steam clock is nice.Be careful in this area.

title: Unique lamp posts, and steam clock
reviews: We parked in the parking garage right on Water St.  The lamp posts and flowers are really spectacular.  The steam clock is unique, and goes off quite frequently.  Just look for all the people with their cameras, and you'll know that you've arrived at the steam clock.Some of the stores are quite nice, with quality goods.  Others are selling the cheap t-shirts, and cheap souvenirs.  Others are vacant.  There were a lot of restaurants, but we didn't get a chance to try any of them out.  I couldn't spend more than an hour in the area.  But it's worth a drive through, just to see the lamp posts, and the steam clock.

title: Gastown
reviews: A great little spot to walk to, the clock  as fascinating wrth the walk

title: up and coming neighbourhood
reviews: hidden treasures vis a vis bistros, pubs, shopping

title: Want a little different slice of life in Vancouver?
reviews: Truly unique retail and restaurant scene from anything I have seen before. Lots of retail variety and plenty of pubs and restaurants with their own unique "flavor". Take at least a half-day to do this area justice! You'll love it.

title: Felt like being in Europe
reviews: Walked through Gastown one lunchtime and it had a different feel to other parts of Vancouver I had seen. The architecture and the feel of the place were more European, it was like being in parts of old London or Paris with the cobbled pavements and the variety of shops.We saw the steam clock, chatted to a busker with his gorgeous husky dog and went for lunch in a great Lebanese restaurant. Lots of people were bustling about, not just tourists but workers getting their lunch. We found a few interesting shops and I stumbled upon a wonderful fabric and haberdashery shop called Dressew which a TA member had told me about before I went to Vancouver but I had not realised it was here. As an avid sewer, I went in and bought some stuff to take home. It's a great shop for sewers and crafters with lots of stuff and cheap prices. Will be back next time I am here.Only one thing spoiled the walk; a guy bumped into me and was really aggressive and even though I said " Sorry" politely, he got aggressive and started following us so we ducked into a shop till he had gone! Apart from this, it was an interesting few hours and enjoyed the walk.

title: Nice but we expected more !
reviews: We had high expectations when we entered the limits of Gastown in Vancouver but we  quicly felt disappointed by the high number of tourist shops and residential buildings !    The place has some interesting historical sites , nice view - points and as an aura of the 19th century but there is a prominent feeling of being tourist oriented with too many souvenir stores and caf√©s !      Worth an 1 hour walk to have a look around for things lke the Steam Clock but no more !     Vancouver has much more to offer !

title: Charming!
reviews: Loved walking through Gastown! It is full of cute shops and cafes. Definitely walk through when in Vancouver!

title: see the old gastown and it is just beautiful
reviews: Walked around and saw Aboriginal arts, Chinese arts, and lots of places to spend money well organized.

title: Touristy... Seedy...
reviews: Clean out the bums, and I might come back... Does not seem like a good introduction to Vancouver for the cruise ship passengers...

title: Parking, ICK!
reviews: The cross section of visitors from the world is amazing, and it is great area to poke around for a day.  Very historical in a rather young country, but parking your car is no day at the beach!  Better to take transit or walk, which is also a good time.

title: Bustling tourist area.
reviews: My best friend took me on a 2 - 3 hour walk through Gastown in Vancouver when we visited last October.  What was our destination?  We didn't have one.  We wandered through some of the shops, walked the streets for blocks and blocks and I got some fabulous pictures.  It is an area of immense interest with so many interesting shops, people watching, and admiring the old buildings.  It is an area of Vancouver that I would highly recommend to visit to tourists and those that enjoy the many unique shops.

title: Perfect for an afternoon
reviews: We spent a few hours here and loved the people watching, window shopping and food options. The stores are unique, the people vibrant and a totally walk able area.

title: come and see this area
reviews: Lots of history, shopping opportunities, and nice eateries, all in walking distance. A must, when you are in Vancouver.

title: Lots of historic facts to find
reviews: Small area filled with history and quaint shops.  There‚Äôs more to Gastown than just Water and Powell Streets.  Be sure to venture further to experience all that Gastown has to offer (shops, cafes, history).

title: Have a wander round the cobbled streets and stop for a beer.
reviews: I really love Gastown. Get a photo of the steam clock and Gassy Jack, take a look in the galleries of native art, grab a souvenir in Hill's and a beer or something to eat at one of the many bars and eateries.

title: Beautiful heritage street
reviews: Quaint shops make this street very unique. I would recommend this spot to turists visiting Vancouver for the first time.

title: Tired...needs new energy!
reviews: Same old souvenier / tourist-trap!  Needs new energy, shops with quality merchandise made by BC craftspeople and artists.  More restaurants offering creative dishes.  Clean it up people - keep shops and streets spotless!

title: Vibrant Must-see
reviews: Plenty of shops from touristy, to higher-end galleries. This is a tourist magnet and the place to buy your Salish Art. There are also plenty of restaurants to suit most ages and budgets as well as a steam clock which is not accurate at all - perhaps why they didn't catch on...?

title: Don't get the hype
reviews: Not really sure why so many people rave about Gastown.  Yes there are some nice restaurants and bars but other than that it's nothing special.  Not bothered by the steam clock or the gassy Jack statue but if you're into that sort of thing then it's definitely worth a visit.

title: They were shooting a TV show but no asked for our autographs !
reviews: We enjoyed just walking the streets of Gaston and thought that the original Gassy Jack Deighton would be delighted with his popularity.  His 1860s saloon is long gone but you can imagine him selling whiskey to the thirsty sawmill workers.  And right where his saloon use to stand, a TV show was being filmed. We watched a little while and there were scores of people working on whatever show it was. After being ignored and no one wanting our autographs, we wandered down another street.  Like many areas of Vancouver, we were repeated approached by panhandlers but not in a threatening or aggressive manner. I bet that old Gassy Jack would have tossed them out of his joint, unless they were buying a drink or two.

title: A quaint little look at our past - too touristy
reviews: This area is quite small overall, and is a nice place to walk through now and then (I am a local).There are lots of shops, and restaurants, as well as interesting historical landmarks.Things that mar this area are the crazy amount of tourity wares being hawked - I think it takes away from the area too much.The other thing is that our homeless and afflicted tend to hand out down here begging for money. (It is close to Main and Hastings - the epicentre). It is an unfortunate reality that affects the area.

title: The unique clock.
reviews: The clock is very nice and the part of town has a very nice atmosphere.

title: Interesting and inviting part of town -- lots of drunk kiddies on the weekends
reviews: It's kind of difficult to rate Gastown as an attraction because it's really a neighborhood. Gastown is fun for walking, shopping, and dining. It's cobbled and has a very charming, old-time feel. There's a lot of history there. I'd love to do a walking tour there!If you like to be out late on the weekends, Gastown will be inundated with folks dressed to impress. It's very hard to snag a cab starting around 1:30. If young, inebriated crowds are not your thing, Gastown can still be for you. Just check it out during the day or on a calm weeknight.

title: Hip vibe
reviews: Can feel a little shady if you turn down the wrong street. A lot of addicts wander down here but also the incredibly hip and upcoming of the city. Good food can be had and look for the steam clock - worth a photo.

title: fun place, great history
reviews: Lots of great history as you walk thru Gastown. I highly recommend a meal at the Speghetti Factory too!

title: The Steam Clock
reviews: An old fashioned town which maintains its character, where restaurants mix with history.  The highlight is the Steam Clock which dates from the 1800's, I believe, and still works.

title: Oldest part of Vancouver
reviews: This was the first part of Vancouver to get a make over, lots of excellent restaurants, shops and historical buildings, home to Gassy Jack and the scene of a disturbance in the early 70's  over marijuana

title: Everyone has to to Gastown
reviews: Place to walk about try some restaurants in the new gassy Jack square area

title: Some Vancouver History
reviews: Used to be just lots and lots of souvenir stores, now there are some very nice Art deco, house and home shops as well.  The steam clock is a must to see.

title: Rated Poor
reviews: Gastown used to be awesome but is well worth the miss now. There used to be all this cool shops but they have all diappeared. It is full of condo's , lofts and a few restraunts. I used to go here every weekend as a kid now I stay clear of Gastown.

title: Tourist shops
reviews: Lots of tourists shops selling t shirts, sweatshirts. There is a steam clock for pictures.

title: funky old area with neat history
reviews: I've visited here many times over the years & while it is still worth visiting, it is getting a little more rundown each time I take visiting friends or family here with some pretty seedy pockets with lots of homeless people.

title: Tattered and grubby.
reviews: This place is grubby.  The panhandlers make is so.  Too bad.  Some good little shops and restaurants, and of course the must see steam clock.

title: Historic district on the rebound
reviews: Gastown is the oldest part of Vancouver and has some interesting vintage buildings. After a number of years in decline on the margins of skid road (with nothing but tacky tourist shops on offer), gastown is on the rebound. There are now many one of a kind shops and restaurants - including some fantastic furniture stores. It is prudent to ensure that you know the boundaries of Gastown before you go. Wander around and window shop, then stop in for a 1st rate meal or cocktail experience.

title: Love Gastown
reviews: One of the best places to visit in Vancouver. Interesting, and recently lost of great gastronomical shops have popped up!

title: Very touristy
reviews: A whole bunch of shops and eateries catering more to the tourist. The steam clock is the center of attention here. Souvenirs abound.

title: Great atmosphere
reviews: Great atmosphere and lots of restaurants and pubs. Limited shopping.

title: A changing neighbourhood
reviews: If you haven't been to Gastown in a few years, you're in for a treat.  Since the Olympics it's gentrifying in a big way with wonderful upscale and downscale eateries and bars.  Yes, there are still homeless folk and seedy hotels, but whereas 2 years ago I would have told people to "skip it.  It's an evil tourist trap", now I want to live there!

title: Historic Gastown
reviews: Great historic old area of Vancouver, lots of restauants & small stores.

title: Touristy
reviews: There are some cool old buildings in Gastown, and some decent restaurants, but unless you are visiting for more than a week, there are far more interesting things to do in Vancouver.

title: A nice walk in the old town
reviews: It is nice to go through Gastown, but we noticed some people trying to take advantage of tourists.  Be careful!

title: Quaint even if it's a little touristy
reviews: Great place to hang out and people watch.  Great vibe, some interesting shops and galleries.  Has a completely different feel at night, especially if it's raining.

title: Some alright clothign stores & tourist trap...
reviews: Like how they have some alternative stores such as deadly couture, more punk,goth,fetish etc clothing. Venus and Mars...though no clothing I have ever found there. Also New World can have some indie designers of clothing, which makes good quality unique garments sometimes.  Also recommend Scottish candy store, near touristy part of cobblestone Gastown.  Warning, for anyone alternative (goth,punk etc), their nightlife in this area SUCKS! Especially sin City stupid dress codes and horrible music. They wanted me to take my shirt off and I refused got my money back and left. Vancouver beautiful city but still can work on it's nightlife. Maybe I missed something?

title: Nice walk interesting area
reviews: Like the shops and history of this district particularly the steam clock playing 'Pompey chimes' but easy to wander into a rough area from here. There are lots of people living on the streets and some roads are uncomfortable.

title: Historical area
reviews: Lots to see and shop in this older part of the city.  DON"T go beyond this area, as it's something you won't want to experience.  That area is known as the Downtown Eastside and although safe you may get hastled for money.  It's known as Canada's poorest postal code.

title: Gastown Vancouver
reviews: A interesting place to wander around.  Different restaurants.  A must in you are in Vancouver.

title: The oldest part of the city - where it all began
reviews: This is a heritage area, so full of charm and interesting stores and restaurants.

title: Just OK
reviews: Gastown has changed over the years.  It needs to have more interesting shops.  Lacks interest.

title: Ghosts??
reviews: Neat buildings cool place minus all the souvenir shops. Check out the haunted old spaghetti factory. Just ask the people that work there.

title: Gastown
reviews: Popular in the 70's, this has gone thru a renovation and remains a popular location for shopping, restaurants and walking around enjoying the cobblestone streets and older buildings

title: Gastown
reviews: The oldest part of Vancouver...nice old buildings...restaurants, a few night clubs, and tourist shopping

title: Disappointing visit
reviews: Past its prime in places to see and go to in Vancouver

title: Gastown
reviews: It is very interesting to walk around and see all the old buildings. They are restored to their original glory.

title: So many really interesting restaurant options.
reviews: Some night out in vancouver, we just head to Gastown and see whats new, or changed.  Seems the unique and talented restaurant folks have decided to take over the area.  No big chains, just cool unique spots.  could eat here for a month straight.

title: Funky part of Downtown Vancouver!
reviews: Lots of Shops, Restaurants and Coffee Bars.  Located near the Water.  Great views of the North Shore.  Home of the Famous 'Steam Clock'!

title: Overdone tourist trap
reviews: I used to work in Gastown and it definitely has come along in the last few years with better shops and restaurants.  Brioche is a great little cafe that you must try.  But gastown itself is a bit over done.

title: Don't visit for the tourist sights
reviews: Gastown is great -- if you live here, know what you're doing, and are going out to dinner.  If you're a tourist, skip it.  The steam clock is underwhelming at best.  There are a bunch of tacky souvenir stores, if that's your thing.  It's the cutting edge of Vancouver food and clothing -- but it's not for tourists.  And you have to understand that Gastown = Downtown East Side (the poorest postal code in Canada).

title: touristy
reviews: Gastown is for tourists. If you need to buy "Vancouver" stuff, or little totem poles this is the place to go. There are now a few lovely native carving shops and galleries but mainly locals don't go there... for instance we do not eat at the old Spagetti factory, because Vancouverites are true foodies and like real Italian food

title: Go for the steam clock
reviews: And that is about it, the stores are constantly changing, often for the worse.

title: Hailing all Crackheads
reviews: The area has some historical significance.  Here is where Gassy Jack Dalton opened a bar and the city of Vancouver was born.  Some neat architecture around the Hotel Europe...etc.  However the politicians in Vancouver think the best thing to bring in tourist is to open Methadone dispensaries and Needle exchanges,  If you want to be held up by scum with an HIV infected needle definatly go to Gastown after dark.

title: Not Much To It...
reviews: There's an old steam clock... which is about as cool as it gets. Some cobblestone walkways. Some buildings. Directly beside Chinatown and the Main Street area, not far from False Creek. Not that impressive if you ask me.

title: Very nice place
reviews: I walked there from Downtown and saw different shops on the streets and you should walk around there too. Also some nice caffe and restaurants and bars are this area. Streets have a lot of flowers with nice view. Lots of gift shops around too and some Indian wood gifts. it is really beautiful area in Downtown. You can buy your gifts in these shops with a lot of goods.

title: up and coming
reviews: The brochures said "up and coming neighborhood" Lots of cheap little shops for tourists. The Steam Clock is a MUST SEE. But dont go there after dark. Very little parking available, a lot of rundown buildings and shady motels, lots of homeless and generally not a safe place at night.

title: Over Rated
reviews: Caught a taxi and expected more. Lots of places were shut (off season) but generally dissapointed. Had a nice meal, saw the gas clock go off and wet back to the hotel.

title: Tourist trap
reviews: Gastown may be marketed as a trendy place to go, it is the biggest tourist trap we found in Vancouver. Tourists everywhere, tacky souvenir shops... A real disappointment! It was also the place where we were hassled & abused by homeless people the most.

title: Historic district
reviews: This place makes you feel like your back in time. It is worth spending a couple of hours.

title: What a fun place!!!
reviews: Had a delightful time visiting Gastown.  Beautiful area, great restaurants, interesting shops, sense of history and easy walking.  Doesn't get much better than that!

title: Beautiful Sunny Day!
reviews: My husband and I drove from Washington to Vancouver, it was my first time ... from many more, I most say ... .. anyway ...regarding Gastown, we went on Labor day weekend, the weather couldn't be nicer, we just walk around, and enjoyed all of its charm. There are many souvenir stores, full of tacky and traditional souvenirs, including the most have ...Maple Syrup!!! The clock is a nice thing to see and hear, there were also street performers and many restaurants. I believe it's a nice aerea to kill an hour.  We really liked it!!

title: Not That Great
reviews: While the main street through Gastown is quite pretty with hanging baskets of flowers and the famous steam clock which is a bit over-rated, there's not much to see here.  There are a few quirky little places but its mostly tacky souvenir shops.  Make sure you don't venture into any side streets, it was a bit seedy with some unsavoury characters hanging around and this was midday.

title: Interesting area to visit
reviews: Go there along with your Chinatown visit.  The two are right next to each other.  You can probably see everything in an hour or two.  A lot of souvenir shops for Vancouver, British Columbia and Canada goodies.  You can find something for everyone.  A bunch of very nice, high-end non-big brand name clothes.  A few nice restaurants, pubs and nightclubs.  Old, but up kept architecture.  It is the most historic area of Vancouver. Start at Waterfront Station and continue east. Right next to Chinatown, which also takes about 1-2 hours so do them both together.

title: Lot's to see in 'old' Gastown
reviews: Gastown definitely have some spots of interest and also some nice places to grab a snack. The best knowledge you will gain by going on a tour with the Vancouver Tour Guys but here are some hints:1) The old Steam Clock. Even though it is from 1977 and runs on electric (= all cheat) then give it a look and here the whistles2) Flagship store of the famous Vancouver Shoe designer John Fluevog3) The Black Frog pub/restaurant - very nice grub. Not to be found on Tripadvisor4) The heads over the doors - these are on the old buildings and not from the re-make of the late 1970's5) at the Waterstreet station you find the first Non-US Starbucks. Not see worthy except if you collect odd sightings though :-)

title: Ok but pray you don't need a restroom
reviews: Nice area to see and shops to visit but if you need a public restroom you are out of luck. Merchants also are not accommodating for use of theirs but are more than happy to take your money for a purchase.

title: not much of anything
reviews: this is a good place for some good souvenir shops but overall there is some seediness to the surrounding area. it is a street of cobble streets with shops and some restaurants. I would not feel comfortable at night there.

title: MUST SEE
reviews: Any visitor to Vancouver should make time to see Gastown. It is easily reached, being a 5 minute walk east from Canada place and the Pan Pacific Hotel.No problem with traffic as all the crossings have pedestrian lights. A safe walk at any time but do not venture further east late at night.Gastown is an amazing mix of old streets, with the famous Steam Clock, tourist shops, specialist shops, and a wide range of restaurants. These range from very cheap spaghetti places, through my favourite Rossinis, which is a great value family Italian restaurant with jazz, to very upmarket (and expensive) establishments. Make sure you pick up some tourist information on "Gassy Jack" after whom the district is named. If you don't get the information you need at your hotel, call at the excellent Tourist Information Office on the ground floor of the tower block across the road from the Pan Pacific Hotel- address is 200 Burrard.  ..

title: Old Town
reviews: Gastown is obviously one of the oldest parts of Downtown Vancouver and has quite a number of old well maintained buildings, so from an architectural point of view it is worth seeing. I also enjoyed the steam clock. Other than that there's not much to see, I covered the area in about half an hour...

title: Interesting, to say the least
reviews: So, we were at the Museum of Anthropology (which was great) when a friend called and wanted to meet us somewhere downtown.  Since none of us were familiar with the city,  I saw a geographical disaster in the making.  But then I referred to the faithful Frommers and said "meet us at the Steam Clock in one hour.  GPS is also helpful.

title: We liked it
reviews: We went to Gastown to catch the Big Bus tour. Lots of souvenir shops, some good restaurants and two marijuana lounges. Fun area

title: Gastown is great!
reviews: My husband and I recently visited Vancouver and spent a great deal of time in Gastown. We stayed at the Fairmont Waterfront Hotel which allowed us a very short walking distance to Gastown which was great.  We dined there frequently, and bought lots of souvenirs there as well. You can spend days walking up and down the street and see so many interesting things.  Definitely go to Gastown while visiting Vancouver, you will be glad that you did.

title: Don't bother
reviews: We just visited Gastown in Vancouver. The downtown district is a bit scary- there are many undesireable homeless

title: Great place to buy souvenirs...but surrounding streets are ghetto
reviews: After reading all the reviews I wasn't planning to go to Gastown but my uncle said we had to see it. So after almost walking all of Vancouver in one day we found ourselves in Gastown...and I'm glad we went. If you walk from the where the cruise ships dock into Gastown its very nice and safe. Gastown itself is very safe and full of tourists. If you walk any of the surrounding streets leading out of Gastown you will find lots of bums and drug dealers. My husband and I were walking out of Gastwon toward Yaletown and while we were at a cross walk a guy on a bike came up to us and asked if we wanted to buy drugs...scary!

title: Worth a quick stroll
reviews: After visiting the Sun Yat-Sen Chinese Garden, we walked through part of Gastown and stopped for a good lunch at the Water Street Cafe.  We enjoyed seeing some of the interesting old architecture.  It's not worth a lot of time, but if you are near the area, it is definitely worth walking through.Granted, we were here during the day, but unlike some of the other reviewers, we didn't find the area scary at all.

title: Don't be scared by the bad reviews here.
reviews: After reading the tips here, I was a bit hesitant about going. We went for an 7:30 p.m. dinner at Steamworks and had a great time. We found close parking and felt very safe the entire time. The restaurant was well-priced and the food was good. (Try the stuffed mushrooms for an appetizer.) We walked around the area after dinner and stopped into a couple of the shops, and while there were a couple "questionable" people on the street, they didn't bother us or anyone else walking down the street. It was no different than walking down the street in my midwestern city. So, go and enjoy.

title: Historical Cobblestone part of Vancouver
reviews: Thanks to Gassy Jack and the cobble stone streets and shops, Gastown is a great destination when visiting Vancouver.  A 2 minute walk from the Sea Bus and the waterfront skytrain station

title: I like Vancouver, but Gastown is an eyesore
reviews: I found Gastown a little unsettling as well.  My wife and I went in the morning, and did the usual tourist stuff. In and out of their shops, but it has the look of a rundown part of town. We are from the Los Angeles area, and drug addicts and panhandlers are not an unusual sight for us. However, in Vancouver it was such a shame to see as the city has the potential of being a world class city.  I love the architecture and Stanley Park.  However, Gastown is worth about an hour, providing you can find a place to park. I will say the steam clock was fun to watch. I would recommend to the city father's of Vancouver, that is, do something about the panhandlers and drug addicts.  They will eventually drive away tourists, and put a blight on your beautiful city.

title: Coolest spot in Vancouver
reviews: Just got back from Vancouver (Im from Toronto) and I thought Gastown was great! Its cool in that its really the only old part of the city I noticed. Really nice, well preserved buildings, but at the same time there is also a modern feel to the ares. Good reastuarants (Cobre was amazing), great patios to sit on and have a drink (Chill Wintson has two huge patios in a small square there) and some cool bars/clubs (I went to Blarney Stone, and Irish bar/club; mainly a university crowd). It also had a lot of shopping (which Im not one for, but my fiance dragged me around). She really liked the small local designer shops that are all over. (There were a few where I got stuff too) And some cool art galleries; I got some interesting BC native carvings. On a side note, while I did see a good number of homeless around there and was aware we were near a bad area, I never once was harrassed or felt in danger; I never really even thought about it. Actually, I saw that they had security walking around the streets all the time, so I guess that gave some added piece of mind.While I mainly went to Vancouver for the outdoors activities (which are many and a blast), Gastown was a definite highlight of my trip, so I thought I would share.

title: Old glory
reviews: Fortunately, I didn't read the bad reviews here before I went to visit Gastown. I enjoyed it a lot. I also noticed that like in any other big city, drugs are everywhere in Vancouver, and in every social class, so let's stop pretending. Homeless didn't bother me as much in Chinatown or Gastown as in other parts of the city, so I'm surprised some of you mention them here. To those who were affraid to get out of their cars : maybe you should buy yourselves a home in Disneyland!To the owners of the area : great restoration job. The european roots are clearly visible, and I hope they will stay forever.

title: Worth Seeing Once!
reviews: We visited Gastown mid-evening. There were loads of touristy stores with all sorts of Vancouver merchandise. There were also quite a few street people as well, though most did not bother us for money. We walked from the Lookout Tower area down to Gastown, but would recommend taking a taxi from Yaletown/BC Place areas as the streets surrounding Gastown were teeming with homeless people and less desirable scenery. The steam-powered clock was neat to see. Also, would recommend a meal at the Old Spaghetti Factory in Gastown, prices are reasonable and meals include soup/salad, entree, bread and spumoni ice cream for dessert. The interior of the restaurant is pretty cool as well, with an old trolley right in the middle of the dining room that you are able to dine in. Families with children would probably like this restaurant. It is worth seeing Gastown once though, if not just to eat at the Old Spaghetti Factory!

title: pleasantly surprised after all the bad reviews
reviews: It seemed family friendly, touristy, yet  nicer, more authentic and tastefully done than the Americans do their touristy streets with shops.  perhaps the area has improved this year as it's scary only if you've never been outside of your living room.  only a couple of blocks, some distance out of the way, had the "druggies and streetlife", but they were too preoccupied with their own problems to bother anyone else it seemed that day.i gave it an above average rating because it was much nicer than i expected.  if my expectations would have been high, i would have given it a neutral or average, but then, i'm not big on these sorts of attractions.

title: Don't be scared
reviews: Gastown is the oldest part of Vancouver. Great tourist shops and bars. Set up as a tourist area in the 1970s, it is currently being renovated and is a great place to see old Vancouver. Don't miss Storeyum, an excellent museum. Don't confuse Gastown with the Downtown Eastside, which is only a few blocks away. While there are many drug addicts on those streets, they are more a danger to themselves than anyone else. I work in the Downtown Eastside and I have never heard of a tourist being mugged (guns are rare in Canada too). On your way to Chinatown, stick to the main streets and you should be OK, though it is distressing to see so many people in such a terrible state. Don't miss Chinatown just because you want to aviod the Downtown Eastside. Next year (2007) Carrall Street will be made a green zone and you will be able to walk from the end of Water Street to the end of Chinatown (Pender Street) avoiding the worst parts of the Downtown Eastside, but even now you can walk without fear. As for the homelessness - Vancouver has a huge homeless problem in general and you will see it everywhere in the city. As the 2010 Olympics approach, many landlords who offer low-income housing are converting the buildings, creating a huge problem for the city.

title: very dodgy area
reviews: I read all the hype about Gastown and Chinatown in the guidebooks but none of them mentioned the fact that they are surrounded by some of the worst areas of Vancouver.My wife and I walked to gastown once and didnt even get as far as china town because gastown is basically a couple of nice streets surrounded by drug dens, prostitutes, addicts cooking drugs in the street etc.. This should be mentioned in guide books because we were prime targets for a mugging but we followed the rule of head down and keep walking, no eye contact and no maps, wallet or camera in view.Saying that, it did at least have a high police presence which is more I can say for the ghetto areas of the UK.get a taxi to take you to the nice street and dont stray outside it.I am a firefighter so went over to have a chat to the Vancouver guys when they were at a job. They were stationed in or near gastown and couldn't believe we had walked through the areas I mentioned (and these are BIG guys I was talking to). Just that morning one of the firefighters had seen 2 muggings and a prostitute "going about her business" on his way to work. We were lucky to get off scott free he said!!At one point we walked past a park and at first thought "phew, a park full of kids, we must be safer now" - NOPE, as we got closer we realised they were not kids but groups of addicts. vancouver seriously needs to sort that area out because it is too close to the tourist area for comfort.

title: My kids were scared to death
reviews: We drove through gastown, but didn't dare stop and get out of the car.  My children were almost in tears, because they were so scared.  Squalor, drug addicts, filth, graffiti - NO THANKS!

title: Vancouver Heritage
reviews: As the birthplace of Vancouver Gastown is a must visit. Gastown is accessible from the Waterfront skytrain stop and is full of unique shops and restaurants. Highlights include the steam clock, blood ally, the statue of founder "Gassy" Jack found in maple tree square and Storyeum. Gastown has many historic buildings, including some very unusual triangular ones build because of land rights. In recent years Gastown has undergone a renovation and is now tourist friendly. Just be sure to say on Water Street (so called because the waters edge used to rise right up to steet level) - wandering too far off will lead you into some less desirable areas.

title: Certainly a Daylight Adventure
reviews: Like other reviews, many homeless and drug addicts, some aggressive. The buildings are worth seeng, but the rest is just t-shirt shops and a couple bars. Not a great tourist attraction. Do it in the daytime!!!

title: Depressing Squalor
reviews: Vancouver is certainly a beautiful city, and Gastown boasts some of the oldest architecture in the country. Unfortunately, this is also home to the one of the worst drug cultures in North America. There are drug addicts, homeless people, and all manner of vagrancy everywhere you look. I've never seen anything like it. It was so depressing that we could hardly stand it. Also, the entire area was a ghost-town by midnight. Very creepy.
